intro: Phlomoides baburii, commonly known as the Afghan phlomoides, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the family Lamiaceae, which includes many aromatic plants known for their medicinal and culinary uses. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is characterized by its slender stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually pale blue to purple, arranged in whorled clusters, and bloom during the summer months. Phlomoides baburii is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
